revision.text:
{{update|date=November 2010}} {{Infobox company | name = Record-Rama | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = | founder = Paul C. Mawhinney | defunct = | location_city = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] | location_country = [[United States]] | location = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] | locations = | area_served = [[North America]] | key_people = Paul C. Mawhinney | industry = Music retailer | products = [[Gramophone record|Records]], [[Compact Cassette|cassettes]] and [[Compact Disc|CDs]] | services = | owner = Paul C. Mawhinney | homepage = [http://www.recordrama.com/ RecordRama.com] }} '''Record-Rama''' was the name of a [[Gramophone record|record]] and [[Compact Disc|CD]] store in [[Pittsburgh]]. It was founded by Paul C. Mawhinney, who claimed he built the world's biggest [[record collecting|record collection]].<ref name="failed-deals-1">{{cite news | title = Failed deals for fabled musical archive strike sour note with owner, page1 | first = Tim | last = Schooley | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/stories/2003/04/28/story6.html | periodical = [[Pittsburgh Business Times]] | publisher = American City Business Journals | issn = 1549-1927 | oclc = 40562053 | date = April 25, 2003 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref>
== Beginnings == Record-Rama was founded by Paul C. Mawhinney, a collector of vinyl records. According to the store's website, Mawhinney was a significant help in restarting [[David Bowie]]'s career by getting fellow Pittsburgher and [[RCA]] boss [[Tom Cossie]] to re-release the album ''[[Space Oddity (album)|Space Oddity]]'' in 1972 after its initial release in 1969 failed to hit.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.recordrama.com/david_bowie.htm |title=David Bowie Story |accessdate=2009-10-19 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715164146/http://www.recordrama.com/david_bowie.htm |archivedate=July 15, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Mawhinney started the shop after his personal collection reached the many thousands. It was his wife who told him to get rid of the records or start a business around them. By the mid-1990s, Record-Rama was doing $5 million (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|5|1994|r=1}}}} million today) a year of business.<ref name="failed-deals-2">{{cite news | title = Failed deals for fabled musical archive strike sour note with owner, page2 | first = Tim | last = Schooley | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/stories/2003/04/28/story6.html?page=2 | periodical = [[Pittsburgh Business Times]] | publisher = American City Business Journals | issn = 1549-1927 | oclc = 40562053 | date = April 25, 2003 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref> In the years that followed, Mawhinney built the world's biggest record collection. He also cataloged records in a directory called the ''MusicMaster''.<ref name="failed-deals-2" /> Mawhinney released the first edition in 1982, and it came in two volumes: one listing by artist, the other by title.<ref>[http://worldjournal-gs.blogspot.com/2009/01/record-rama-archives.html Record-Rama Archives] blog on [[Blogger (service)|Blogger]]. Retrieved 2009-10-19. {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wNa9ZWk5?url=http://worldjournal-gs.blogspot.com/2009/01/record-rama-archives.html |date=9 February 2011 }}</ref> By 2003, the business had dropped to $500,000 a year, one tenth of what it had been. Mawhinney attributed the drop in sales to large retailers who were able to sell recorded music below cost and illegal Internet downloading.<ref name="failed-deals-2" />
== Closure == Record-Rama closed in the summer of 2008 during the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010|global credit crunch]]. <ref name="closes">{{cite news |title = Record-Rama closes |url = http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/breaking/s_584384.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080824222220/http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/breaking/s_584384.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = August 24, 2008 |agency = [[Associated Press]] |newspaper = [[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]] |publisher = Tribune-Review Publishing Company |oclc = 33822100 |date = August 22, 2008 |accessdate = 19 August 2010 |df = }} </ref> Mawhinney stated that he had been squeezed out of business by the recording industry and large retailers who can sell compact discs to the public for less than his wholesale costs.<ref name="closes" />
== The biggest record collection on Earth == Mawhinney started his record collection in 1951. The first record he bought was [[Frankie Laine]]'s "[[Jezebel (song)|Jezebel]]". Mawhinney built his collection into the thousands before he founded Record-Rama. After he set up shop, he decided to keep and archive one copy of every record he sold. In 2003, at over 2 million items, Mawhinney's collection was more than twice the size of the collection at the [[Library of Congress]].<ref name="failed-deals-2" /> By the time the store closed in 2008, the collection stood at more than three million items and was valued at [[United States dollar|$]]50 million (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|50|2008|r=1}}}} million today).<ref name="worlds-greatest">{{cite news | title = World's greatest music collection goes on sale | first = Sean | last = Michaels | url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/feb/19/news | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = The Guardian | issn = 0261-3077 | oclc = 60623878 | date = 19 February 2008 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref>
== Attempts to sell == Mawhinney first attempted to sell the collection in 1997. According to the owner, [[CD Now]] offered $28.5 million (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|28.5|1997|r=1}}}} million today) for the collection plus a $100,000/year job (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|100000|1997}}}} today) to Mawhinney to administer the archive.<ref name="failed-deals-1" /><ref name="worlds-greatest" /> Mawhinney claims the sale fell through three weeks later when CD Now went to bankruptcy court.<ref name="failed-deals-1" />
In the fall of 2002, Mawhinney and the Library of Congress were actively discussing the sale of Mawhinney's collection.<ref name="failed-deals-2" /> The parties were unable to reach an agreement due to the scarcity of federal funding and difficulties justifying the purchase using taxpayer dollars.<ref name="failed-deals-2" /> The Library of Congress denies the parties had reached an agreement.
In 2008, Mawhinney closed his shop and needed to sell the record archive.<ref>{{cite news |title = Pine record collector selling 'history of music' |first = Regis |last = Behe |url = http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/ae/music/s_547964.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090803024125/http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/ae/music/s_547964.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = August 3, 2009 |newspaper = [[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]] |publisher = Tribune-Review Publishing Company |oclc = 33822100 |date = January 18, 2008 |accessdate = 18 August 2010 |df = }} </ref> Mawhinney listed the collection for sale on [[eBay]] in February 2008.<ref>{{Citation | last = Van Buskirk | first = Eliot | date = February 19, 2008 | title = ‘World’s Greatest Record Collection’ for Sale on eBay | periodical = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | publisher =Condé Nast Publications | url = https://www.wired.com/2008/02/worlds-largest-2/ | issn = 1059-1028 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref> He received a winning bid of $3,002,150 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|3.00215|2008|r=2}}}} million today) from a buyer in Ireland.<ref>{{cite news | title = Record-Rama collection sells for $3M | first = Ben | last = Semmes | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/stories/2008/02/18/daily43.html | periodical = [[Pittsburgh Business Times]] | publisher = American City Business Journals | issn = 1549-1927 | oclc = 40562053 | date = February 22, 2008 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref> A few days later, however, eBay suspended the bidder's account and advised Mawhinney that the bid was not legitimate.<ref>{{cite news | title = $3m vinyl sale is scratched | first = Sean | last = Michaels | url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/feb/26/news | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = The Guardian | issn = 0261-3077 | oclc = 60623878 | date = 26 February 2008 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Record Rama bidder turns out to be a fraud | first = Scott | last = Mervis | url = http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/2008/02/23/Record-Rama-bidder-turns-out-to-be-a-fraud/stories/200802230165 | newspaper = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | publisher = John Robinson Block | issn = 1068-624X | date = February 23, 2008 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref> Mawhinney relisted the collection in March 2008<ref>{{Citation | last = Van Buskirk | first = Eliot | date = March 24, 2008 | title = ‘World’s Greatest Record Collection’ For Sale… Again | periodical = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | publisher =Condé Nast Publications | url = https://www.wired.com/listening_post/2008/03/worlds-greatest/ | issn = 1059-1028 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Record-Rama music collection for sale again | first = Ben | last = Semmes | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/stories/2008/03/10/daily34.html | periodical = [[Pittsburgh Business Times]] | publisher = American City Business Journals | issn = 1549-1927 | oclc = 40562053 | date = March 13, 2008 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref> but it did not sell.
By 2012, Mawhinney had sold various sections of the archive and various formats to other interested individuals. {{citation needed|date=February 2017}} The remains of a once-great collection were housed in a number of storage units that were in danger of being auctioned off due to the cost of maintenance by somebody on a fixed income with no retirement funds.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}}
Plans for preservation of the archive were set in motion by ''Audio Preservation Fund'' in 2012 with the intent to open a [[museum]], [[online database]], and [[retailing|shop]] under the name ''The Worlds Greatest Music Collection''. Efforts to raise funds to purchase the collection failed, and the Audio Preservation Fund and Mawhinney parted ways when, once again, the prospector went out of business.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paul Mawhinney and The Worlds Largest Record Collection|url=http://www.chaoscartel.com.au/2013/news-paul-mawhinney-and-the-worlds-largest-record-collection/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005013354/http://www.chaoscartel.com.au/2013/news-paul-mawhinney-and-the-worlds-largest-record-collection/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 October 2013|publisher=Chaos Cartel|accessdate=2 October 2013}} </ref>
== Sale == In 2013, a friend of Mawhinney’s told him about a classified ad in [[Billboard Magazine]]: "RECORD COLLECTIONS. We BUY any record collection. Any style of music. We pay HIGHER prices than anyone else." <ref name="brazilian-bus">{{Citation | last = Reel | first = Monte | date = 2014-08-08 | title = The Brazilian Bus Magnate Who’s Buying Up All the World’s Vinyl Records | periodical = The New York Times Magazine | publisher = The New York Times Company | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/10/magazine/the-brazilian-bus-magnate-whos-buying-up-all-the-worlds-vinyl-records.html?_r=0 | accessdate = 25 February 2017 }}</ref> Mawhinney made contact with the buyer's agent, and in the fall of 2013, eight {{nowrap|16 meter}} long [[Semi-trailer truck|semis]] pulled up to Mawhinney's warehouse and departed with what remained of the archive.<ref name="brazilian-bus" /> The buyer was [[Zero Freitas]] of São Paulo, Brazil, a Brazilian bus magnate.<ref name="brazilian-bus" /> As of August 2014, Freitas had 17 [[Internship|interns]] cataloging and recording {{nowrap|500 records}} a day, and he planned to open an online museum.<ref>http://money.cnn.com/video/news/2014/08/29/brazil-largest-vinyl-record-collection-sao-paulo.cnnmoney/index.html?iid=GM</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links ==
=== Further reading === * ''[http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/breaking/s_584384.html Record-Rama closes]'', article on [[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]. * ''[http://www.vimeo.com/1546186 The Archive]'', video about the plight of the Paul Mawhinney and his collection, on [[Vimeo]].
=== Main links === * [http://www.recordrama.com Record-Rama] — official website. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080822002859/http://www.thegreatestmusiccollection.com/index.html The Worlds Greatest Music Collection] at the [[Internet Archive]] — (former) official website.
{{Pittsburgh}}
[[Category:Music retailers of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in Pittsburgh]] [[Category:Music archives]]

'''Roving reference''', also called '''roaming reference''', is a library service model in which, instead of being positioned at a static [[reference desk]], a [[librarian]] moves throughout the library to locate patrons with questions or concerns and offer them help in finding or using library resources.<ref name=ifla>{{Cite web|url=http://archive.ifla.org/VII/dg/dgrw/dp99-05.htm|publisher=IFLA|title=Roving Reference: A New Approach to User Services|author1=Courtois, Martin |author2=Liriano, Maira |date=31 May 1999}}</ref>
==History== Roving reference as a library service practice was first formalized in the late 1980s and early 1990s. A 1999 report from the [[International Federation of Library Associations]] identified several advantages and disadvantages with roving reference in the pre-mobile era. The roving model allowed librarians to engage with "the majority of users who have questions in mind [who] do not approach the reference desk for assistance".<ref name=ifla/> However, libraries reported that some staff were uncomfortable with the practice, and that there were concerns about user privacy.<ref name=ifla/>
Beginning in the 2000s, librarians used laptops or laptop carts to engage in technology-supported roaming reference. Since the development of mobile technologies, roving reference can be facilitated with the use of such technologies, such as [[tablet computer]]s, which allow librarians to readily check the [[online public access catalogue]] or the library's electronic databases while away from their desk.<ref>Smith, Annie; Stevens, Mark (2012). "We're Going Mobile: Roving Reference in an Academic Library" Utah Library Association.</ref> This has contributed to the increased popularization of roving-reference programs as supplements for more traditional reference desks. The model has also been extended to service beyond the library building (library outreach), for example in a dormitory or faculty building at an academic institution.<ref>{{cite book|editors=Bowers, Jennifer; Forbes, Carrie|title=Rethinking Reference for Academic Libraries: Innovative Developments and Future Trends|year=2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|chapter=Roving Reference|author=Wilkinson, Zara|pages=85–98|isbn=9781442244535}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Reference]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Sight & Sound | logo = | logo_size = | image_file = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | editor = [[Nick James (critic)|Nick James]] | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = Film | frequency = Monthly | circulation = | publisher = [[British Film Institute]] | founder = | founded = 1932 | firstdate = | company = | country = United Kingdom | based = | language = English | website = {{URL|http://www.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/}} | issn = 0037-4806 | oclc = }} '''''Sight & Sound''''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] monthly [[film]] [[magazine]] published by the [[British Film Institute]] (BFI). ==History and content== ''Sight & Sound'' was first published in 1932 and in 1934 management of the magazine was handed to the nascent BFI, which still publishes the magazine today. ''Sight & Sound'' was published quarterly for most of its history until the early 1990s, apart from a brief run as a monthly publication in the early 1950s, but in 1991 it merged with another BFI publication, the ''[[Monthly Film Bulletin]]'', and started to appear monthly. The journal was edited by [[Gavin Lambert]] from 1949 to 1955, and from 1956 to 1990 by [[Penelope Houston (film critic)|Penelope Houston]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/penelope-houston-vital-commentator-on-post-war-cinema-who-edited-the-bfi-s-sight-sound-film-magazine-a6715811.html|title=Penelope Houston: Influential editor of 'Sight & Sound' magazine|date=2015-10-30|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-08-24|language=en-GB}} The relaunch editor was [[Philip Dodd (broadcaster)|Philip Dodd]]. It is currently edited by [[Nick James (critic)|Nick James]]. The magazine reviews all film releases each month, including those with a limited ([[art film|art house]]) release, as opposed to most film magazines which concentrate on those films with a general release. ''Sight & Sound'' features a full cast and crew credit list for each reviewed film, as well as the entire plot of said film. ==The ''Sight & Sound'' Poll of the Greatest Films of All Time== Every decade, ''Sight & Sound'' asks an international group of film professionals to vote for their ten [[Films considered the greatest ever|greatest films of all time]]. Until 1992, the votes of the invited critics and directors were compiled to make one list. However, since 1992, directors have been invited to participate in a separate poll. The individual results are eclectic; in the 2002 poll, 885 different films received at least one mention from one voter. Even the top-of-the-list consensus has its limits. In 2002, both the critics and the directors selected [[Stanley Kubrick]] films in their top ten; however, the critics chose ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'', while the directors preferred ''[[Dr. Strangelove]]''. The ''Sight & Sound'' accolade has come to be regarded as one of the most important of the "greatest ever film" polls. [[Roger Ebert]] described it as "by far the most respected of the countless polls of great movies—the only one most serious movie people take seriously."{{cite web | title='Citizen Kane' fave film of movie elite | work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] | author = Roger Ebert | authorlink = Roger Ebert | url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20020811/COMMENTARY/88010305 |accessdate=2008-01-01 }} The first poll, in 1952, was topped by ''[[Bicycle Thieves]]''. The five subsequent polls (1962–2002) were won by ''[[Citizen Kane]]'' (which finished 13th in 1952), while ''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'' received the most votes in 2012.Johnson, Eric C. [http://alumnus.caltech.edu/~ejohnson/sight/1952.html Sight and Sound Poll 1952: Critics], [[Caltech]]. Only ''[[La Règle du jeu|La Règle du jeu (The Rules of the Game)]]'' has appeared in all seven of the magazine's decennial polls. Among the directors that participated in 2012 are [[Quentin Tarantino]], [[Martin Scorsese]], [[Ken Loach]] and [[Francis Ford Coppola]]. ''Sight & Sound'' has in the past been the subject of criticism, notably from [[Raymond Durgnat]], who often accused it of elitism, puritanism and snobbery, although he did write for it in the 1950s, and again in the 1990s.{{cite web|last1=Miller|first1=Henry K.|title=Poetry in motion|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/features/poetry-motion|website=BFI Film Forever|publisher=BFI|accessdate=14 November 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Gough-Yates|first1=Kevin|title=Raymond Who?|url=http://www.raymonddurgnat.com/|website=Raymond Durgnat.com|publisher=The Estate of Raymond Durgnat|accessdate=14 November 2014}} The magazine's American counterpart is ''[[Film Comment]]'', a magazine published by the [[Film Society of Lincoln Center]] in New York City.[http://www.filmreference.com/encyclopedia/Independent-Film-Road-Movies/Journals-and-Magazines-ACADEMIC-JOURNALS.html Academic Journals] It has also been accused of populism in recent years.[http://articles.latimes.com/2012/aug/02/entertainment/la-et-mn-citizen-kane-vs-vertigo-what-does-sight-sound-poll-really-mean-20120802] ===Critics' Top Ten Poll=== ====1952====

Closest runners-up: ''[[Bicycle Thieves]]'' and ''[[Singin' in the Rain]]''. (10 mentions apiece) ====2002====
  1. ''[[Citizen Kane]]'' (46 mentions)

  3. ''[[The Rules of the Game]]'' (30 mentions)
  4. ''[[The Godfather]]'' and ''[[The Godfather Part II]]'' (23 mentions)

  6. ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' (21 mentions)

Closest runners-up: ''[[Seven Samurai]]'' and ''[[The Searchers (film)|The Searchers]]''. (15 mentions apiece) ====2012==== [[File:Vertigo 1958 trailer Kim Novak at Golden Gate Bridge Fort Point.jpg|thumb|[[Vertigo (film)|''Vertigo'']] (1958)]] {{Main|The Sight & Sound Top 50 Greatest Films of All Time}} A new rule was imposed for this ballot: related films that are considered part of a larger whole (e.g. ''The Godfather'' and ''The Godfather Part II'', [[Krzysztof Kieślowski]]'s ''[[Three Colors trilogy]]'' and ''[[Dekalog]]'', or [[Satyajit Ray]]'s ''[[The Apu Trilogy]]'') were to be treated as separate films for voting purposes. For the 2012 poll, ''Sight & Sound'' also listened to decades of criticism about the lack of diversity of its poll participants and made a huge effort to invite a much wider variety of critics and filmmakers from around the world to participate, taking into account gender, ethnicity, race, geographical region, socioeconomic status, and other kinds of underrepresentation. # ''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'' (191 mentions) # ''[[Citizen Kane]]'' (157 mentions) # ''[[Tokyo Story]]'' (107 mentions) # ''[[The Rules of the Game]]'' (100 mentions) # ''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'' (93 mentions) # ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' (90 mentions) # ''[[The Searchers (film)|The Searchers]]'' (78 mentions) # ''[[Man with a Movie Camera]]'' (68 mentions) # ''[[The Passion of Joan of Arc]]'' (65 mentions) # ''[[8½]]'' (64 mentions) Closest runner-up: ''[[Battleship Potemkin]]''. '''''The Oxford Dictionary of Islam''''' is a [[dictionary]] of [[Islam]], published by the [[Oxford University Press]], with [[John Esposito]] as editor-in-chief.
==Overview== The dictionary contains over 2,000 entries on a wide range of Islamic related topics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0195125592/|title=The Oxford Dictionary of Islam|accessdate=2012-09-03|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}}</ref>
